articles.headline: What Amazon, the F.T.C. and C.I.A. Won’t Say When You’ve Been Scammed
articles.snippet: New York magazine’s money columnist wrote about being conned out of $50,000 by crooks pretending to be from Amazon and government agencies. We asked the company and agencies for comment.
articles.abstract: New York magazine’s money columnist wrote about being conned out of $50,000 by crooks pretending to be from Amazon and government agencies. We asked the company and agencies for comment.
articles.lead_paragraph: When New York magazine’s finance advice columnist dropped an article that went viral on Thursday about falling victim to a $50,000 scam, my heart skipped a beat.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: In Prison or Out, Navalny Was the Thorn in Putin’s Side
articles.snippet: A straight-talking former real estate lawyer, he stayed relevant even from prison, pleading with Russians not to give up or give in to their fears and railing against the “criminal” war in Ukraine.
articles.abstract: A straight-talking former real estate lawyer, he stayed relevant even from prison, pleading with Russians not to give up or give in to their fears and railing against the “criminal” war in Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: The death of Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, Aleksei A. Navalny, at a remote Arctic prison on Friday ended one of the most audacious political careers of modern times and left wartime Russia without its most charismatic antiwar voice.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski

articles.headline: Avdiivka, Longtime Stronghold for Ukraine, Falls to Russians
articles.snippet: With Ukraine’s forces at risk of encirclement, the top military commander ordered a retreat. In startlingly candid accounts, soldiers described disarray and despair.
articles.abstract: With Ukraine’s forces at risk of encirclement, the top military commander ordered a retreat. In startlingly candid accounts, soldiers described disarray and despair.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ukraine ordered the complete withdrawal from the decimated city of Avdiivka before dawn on Saturday, surrendering a position that had been a military stronghold for the better part of a decade, in the face of withering Russian assault.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall, Marc Santora and Constant Méheut

articles.headline: The Father, the Son and the Fight Over Their King
articles.snippet: A student’s vow to overthrow one of Africa’s last ruling monarchs faces a roadblock: his own father, a soldier sworn to protect the throne.
articles.abstract: A student’s vow to overthrow one of Africa’s last ruling monarchs faces a roadblock: his own father, a soldier sworn to protect the throne.
articles.lead_paragraph: The riot police appeared out of nowhere, charging furiously toward the young protesters trying to oust King Mswati III, who has ruled over the nation of Eswatini for 38 years. The pop of gunfire ricocheted through the streets, and the demonstrators started running for their lives.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Joao Silva

articles.headline: Sweating Buckets, and Loving It: Minnesotans and Their Saunas
articles.snippet: Saunas in the state, part of a tradition with roots in the 1800s, have been especially popular since the pandemic as more people seek a communal experience.
articles.abstract: Saunas in the state, part of a tradition with roots in the 1800s, have been especially popular since the pandemic as more people seek a communal experience.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jumping in a hole in a frozen lake during a subzero Minnesota winter evening is brutal. Your body spasms and you start to hyperventilate. Pain is sharpest in your toes and fingers as the skin turns bright pink. Teeth chattering uncontrollably, you ask yourself: What on earth was I thinking?
articles.byline: By Ernesto Londoño and Jenn Ackerman

articles.headline: Some Good FAFSA News: There’s a Loophole for Grandparents
articles.snippet: Even amid the botched rollout of the new financial aid form, a rule change will let some grandparents help pay for college without compromising aid eligibility.
articles.abstract: Even amid the botched rollout of the new financial aid form, a rule change will let some grandparents help pay for college without compromising aid eligibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a miserable year to be applying for financial aid.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: Trump Allies Plan New Sweeping Abortion Restrictions
articles.snippet: His supporters are seeking to attack abortion rights and abortion access from a variety of angles should he regain the White House, including using a long-dormant law from 1873.
articles.abstract: His supporters are seeking to attack abortion rights and abortion access from a variety of angles should he regain the White House, including using a long-dormant law from 1873.
articles.lead_paragraph: Allies of former President Donald J. Trump and officials who served in his administration are planning ways to restrict abortion rights if he returns to power that would go far beyond proposals for a national ban or the laws enacted in conservative states across the country.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Elizabeth Dias

articles.headline: With Prison Certain and Death Likely, Why Did Navalny Return?
articles.snippet: An activist who thrived on agitation, he feared irrelevancy in exile. Winning new respect as he continued to lambast the Kremlin from behind bars cost him his life.
articles.abstract: An activist who thrived on agitation, he feared irrelevancy in exile. Winning new respect as he continued to lambast the Kremlin from behind bars cost him his life.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was one question that Russians repeatedly asked the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, who died in a remote Arctic penal colony on Friday, and he confessed that he found it a little annoying.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: U.S. Fears Russia Might Put a Nuclear Weapon in Space
articles.snippet: American spy agencies are divided on whether Moscow would go so far, but the concern is urgent enough that Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken has asked China and India to try to talk Russia down.
articles.abstract: American spy agencies are divided on whether Moscow would go so far, but the concern is urgent enough that Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken has asked China and India to try to talk Russia down.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Russia conducted a series of secret military satellite launches around the time of its invasion of Ukraine in early 2022, American intelligence officials began delving into the mystery of what, exactly, the Russians were doing.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: From Frigid Cells to Mystery Injections, Prison Imperiled Navalny’s Health
articles.snippet: Although Aleksei A. Navalny’s cause of death is not known, his staff often worried that brutal conditions imposed on him in ever crueler prisons might lead to his death.
articles.abstract: Although Aleksei A. Navalny’s cause of death is not known, his staff often worried that brutal conditions imposed on him in ever crueler prisons might lead to his death.
articles.lead_paragraph: Aleksei A. Navalny portrayed himself as invincible, consistently using his hallmark humor to suggest that President Vladimir V. Putin couldn’t break him, no matter how dire his conditions became in prison.
articles.byline: By Paul Sonne and Ivan Nechepurenko

articles.headline: A Family Ranch, Swallowed Up in the Madness of the Border
articles.snippet: Desperate migrants. Cartel violence. It’s all happening in the Chiltons’ backyard.
articles.abstract: Desperate migrants. Cartel violence. It’s all happening in the Chiltons’ backyard.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jim Chilton, 84, had named the dirt roads and pastures on his land in honor of four generations of family cattle ranchers, but now he prepared to drive across his ranch on the U.S. border unsure of what he might find. He packed a handgun in case he encountered more smugglers working with the Sinaloa cartel and bottles of water for the migrants he’d recently seen lost and dehydrated in the Sonoran Desert.
articles.byline: By Eli Saslow and Erin Schaff

articles.headline: Kam Ghaffarian’s Moonshots
articles.snippet: The entrepreneur wants to help build the new space economy, one Prada spacesuit and Jeff Koons-filled lunar lander at a time.
articles.abstract: The entrepreneur wants to help build the new space economy, one Prada spacesuit and Jeff Koons-filled lunar lander at a time.
articles.lead_paragraph: Much of the American space program is run out of nondescript offices in the Washington, D.C., suburbs. That’s where Kam Ghaffarian, the billionaire space entrepreneur, could be found on an auspicious day. Exactly 47 years before, he had immigrated to the United States from Iran. Mr. Ghaffarian, 66, sat at a table made of gently glowing white onyx, also from Iran.
articles.byline: By Tim Fernholz

articles.headline: The Death Throes of a Ukrainian City
articles.snippet: Toward the end of Russia’s long assault, hundreds of civilians still remained in Avdiivka. Those who escaped in the last weeks spoke of relentless devastation.
articles.abstract: Toward the end of Russia’s long assault, hundreds of civilians still remained in Avdiivka. Those who escaped in the last weeks spoke of relentless devastation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even from a few miles away, the death rattle of another Ukrainian city echoed through the mist and fog. Russian warplanes were dropping more thousand-pound bombs on Avdiivka in eastern Ukraine, reducing an already battered city to rubble and ashes.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks

articles.headline: Arrested for Leaving Flowers, Navalny Mourners Fear Worse to Come
articles.snippet: At least 366 people were detained over the weekend, leading to concern that the arrests could signal greater government repression ahead of Russia’s elections in March.
articles.abstract: At least 366 people were detained over the weekend, leading to concern that the arrests could signal greater government repression ahead of Russia’s elections in March.
articles.lead_paragraph: A bishop who planned a public prayer for the Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny was detained as he left his house. Two men were arrested for having a photograph of Mr. Navalny in a backpack. Another man who lay flowers at a memorial said he was beaten by police officers for the small act of remembrance.
articles.byline: By Valerie Hopkins

articles.headline: Let Tesla Expand? Three German Teens Have a Few Thoughts.
articles.snippet: The U.S. automaker’s plan to enlarge its operations outside Berlin has divided local residents. Some worry about the environmental costs; others see job prospects.
articles.abstract: The U.S. automaker’s plan to enlarge its operations outside Berlin has divided local residents. Some worry about the environmental costs; others see job prospects.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tesla’s hulking assembly plant outside Berlin, which opened two years ago in a community known for its forests and lakes, still rubs many residents the wrong way. They worry it threatens the quality of their water and air, and has disrupted the peacefulness that drew them to the area.
articles.byline: By Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Shaken by Grisly Killings of Women, Activists in Africa Demand Change
articles.snippet: The continent has the highest rate of gender-related killings of women in the world, according to the United Nations. Activists accuse officials of ignoring the issue and blaming the victims.
articles.abstract: The continent has the highest rate of gender-related killings of women in the world, according to the United Nations. Activists accuse officials of ignoring the issue and blaming the victims.
articles.lead_paragraph: A wave of gruesome killings of women across several African countries in recent weeks has prompted outrage and indignation, triggered a wave of protests and precipitated calls for governments to take decisive action against gender-based violence.
articles.byline: By Abdi Latif Dahir

articles.headline: Anti-Trump Burnout: The Resistance Says It’s Exhausted
articles.snippet: Bracing for yet another election against Donald Trump, America’s liberals are feeling the fatigue. “We’re kind of, like, crises-ed out,” one Democrat said.
articles.abstract: Bracing for yet another election against Donald Trump, America’s liberals are feeling the fatigue. “We’re kind of, like, crises-ed out,” one Democrat said.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2017 they donned pink hats to march on Washington, registering their fury with Donald J. Trump by the hundreds of thousands.
articles.byline: By Katie Glueck

articles.headline: Plans to Expand U.S. Chip Manufacturing Are Running Into Obstacles
articles.snippet: Delays in finishing new factories are emerging, just as the Biden administration begins handing out money to stoke domestic production.
articles.abstract: Delays in finishing new factories are emerging, just as the Biden administration begins handing out money to stoke domestic production.
articles.lead_paragraph: In December 2022, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, the key maker of the world’s most cutting-edge chips, said it planned to spend $40 billion in Arizona on its first major U.S. hub for semiconductor production.
articles.byline: By Don Clark and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: U.S. Awards $1.5 Billion to Chipmaker GlobalFoundries
articles.snippet: The grant will go toward chips for the auto and defense industries, and is the largest award to date from $39 billion in government funding.
articles.abstract: The grant will go toward chips for the auto and defense industries, and is the largest award to date from $39 billion in government funding.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Monday announced a $1.5 billion award to the New York-based chipmaker GlobalFoundries, one of the first sizable grants from a government program aimed at revitalizing semiconductor manufacturing in the United States.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Don Clark

articles.headline: Navalny’s Widow Pledges to Carry On Opposition Leader’s Work
articles.snippet: The sudden death of Aleksei Navalny left a vacuum in Russia’s opposition. His wife, Yulia Navalnaya, signaled that she would try to fill the void.
articles.abstract: The sudden death of Aleksei Navalny left a vacuum in Russia’s opposition. His wife, Yulia Navalnaya, signaled that she would try to fill the void.
articles.lead_paragraph: The widow of Aleksei A. Navalny said on Monday that she would carry on her husband’s work to challenge President Vladimir V. Putin’s autocratic rule, presenting herself for the first time as a political force and calling on his followers to rally alongside her.
articles.byline: By Paul Sonne and Ivan Nechepurenko

articles.headline: Inside Aleksei Navalny’s Final Months, in His Own Words
articles.snippet: Trump. Indian food. Matthew Perry. And books, books, books. Excerpts from letters obtained by The Times show Mr. Navalny’s active mind, even amid brutal prison conditions.
articles.abstract: Trump. Indian food. Matthew Perry. And books, books, books. Excerpts from letters obtained by The Times show Mr. Navalny’s active mind, even amid brutal prison conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Confined to cold, concrete cells and often alone with his books, Aleksei A. Navalny sought solace in letters. To one acquaintance, he wrote in July that no one could understand Russian prison life “without having been here,” adding in his deadpan humor: “But there’s no need to be here.”
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski
